@cancelself Sometimes people are put together almost as if by fate, and you look back and think, imagine if these people had been able to work together instead of trying to trip each other up.
People ought to work together more. I think that's the big bug in our world.

You see it everywhere. Studying the Beatles recently has driven this home. Here were four people who, when working together, had real magic. They worked together for a long time, but they are the total exception.
Tweets, Markdown and RSS go well together.
Pessimism is not wisdom.

# The Twitter-to-RSS project

The project is coming along. Implemented so far...

* Tweets can have titles. Make the first character in a tweet a #. The rest of the first line is the title.

* Full Markdown support. Anything you can type in a tweet can be Markdown and will be rendered as it's converted to an RSS item. Markdown is ideal for where Twitter is at now. It a plain text environment, and that's what MD is designed for.

* Threads are rolled up into the first message, forming one RSS item. In RSS there is no character limit. And Twitter has a good thread composition tool built in. * [Emoji short codes]([link]). This was an easy one so I thought why not.

Not sure how I'll package it for release. I want to wait until the major coding is done before deciding that. 

*Still diggin!*
This is the combination of Twitter + Markdown + RSS. All the basic features of HTML, from within Twitter. No other tools used. As they used to say -- *bing!* :smile: [link]

1/8 I saw a comment that Facebook lost half its market cap because they changed the company's name to Meta. It rings true. It was a really stupid move.
2/8 They changed their name because journalism has the power to shape public opinion and markets. It's amazing to me how much power they still have.
3/8 A few years ago they decided as if by osmosis to conflate the company with the things users do with their service. When the users do something evil, say Facebook did it.
4/8 Say it often enough and it sticks in the mind.
5/8 Facebook == evil. Over and over and over.

6/8 Funny thing is that Facebook the company has the best propaganda machine ever invented, but they don't use it for that purpose. If Zuck et al had chosen to usurp journalism's name shaping ability he could probably have destroyed them.
7/8 It wouldn't have made a difference to me or other people who don't have the power, but you wonder why they didn't use it?
8/8 Sure journalism would have screamed bloody murder. So what. Let them scream.
As a kid, I found Everett Dirksen endlessly entertaining. He was a funny looking guy and had a froggy voice, but he told great stories, the kind of stories a pre-teen boy could get into. [link]

Someday some of you will tweet using Markdown.

It seems to me that Markdown was designed for an environment like Twitter, esp if there's a way to flow tweets to a place where HTML is properly rendered. 

Where **this** will be bold and *this* will be italic.

This is the story of Facebook, but omits that there is a huge part of the FB community that isn't seeking fame, that uses it as a way to communicate for benign even useful purposes. It's like the phone or email that way. [link]

Actually -- a small correction.

Everyone seems to be seeking fame, but our domains are of various sizes.

I live in a small town. I don't want to be famous in the town, but I wouldn't mind making friends through FB.
And we have, in our little town, people who purpously annoy, but the moderation tools in FB seem to keep them from being *too* annoying.

So depressing to read about Dean Paquet, EIC at the NYT and his loathing of "twitter" whatever he means by that. We need one news org that does not just listen to other news orgs and a small group of non-journo elites. One news org to be the example the others will follow.
PS: To @taylorlorenz yes there are exceptions but they are few and far between.

This is exactly the kind of headline journalists fight you on if you say journalism did this or that. Facebook didn't do this, people who use Facebook did. Yeah it matters. Probably a good piece, spoiled by a corrupt headline. [link]

I have a little web app that lets you view an RSS feed in JSON. Turns out can be pretty useful when you just want to see what's in a feed, independent of how the developer formatted it. Here's an example of it viewing my feed. [link]

@ChrisHardie I know it's been tried before, I was one of the people who tried it, but there are reasons to think it will work better in 2022 than it did ten or more years ago. I wrote a piece about this -- [link] I think you'll find it interesting.

@trvr @amszmidt I don't like to argue on twitter, but just want to point out that spotify's radio programs are not mp3s and are not delivered in an rss feed, and you would not be able to listen to them on a sandisk clip.

If the open web had a good lawyer we could stop Spotify from calling their radio programs "podcasts" because it's a fraudulent claim. 

It's like saying a car gets 800 miles per gallon when it gets 30 mpg. It's a lie. People expect podcasts to work in any player. Spotify is lying

@danshipper -- I read your piece about Roam, and I've been curious about the product since I heard people loving the linking it has. I played around with the ideas in my own product, Drummer -- and came to the same conclusion you did.

I went further and implemented a search facility and loaded in about a decade worth of blog posts to it. I love it. Google's search has been degrading for years, but it was never as good as my dedicated search. Here's an example search. [link]

I've been working on outliners for a long time, and I like the direction #toolsforthought has been pulling me. 

I think search is the answer. You shouldn't have to plan in advance for what will be easily findable in the future. You very often have no idea what will be important.

In Frontier we have two verbs that can be used to normalize the formatting of XML files. They are:

xml.compile (xmltext) returns xstruct

xml.decompile (xstruct) returns xmltext

Is there the equivalent in Node.js?
@awbjs thanks! i was kind of surprised how well the pieces fit together now. also servers are a lot cheaper and higher performance, so more is possible there too.

I organized my thinking about Twitter and RSS in this blog post. The environment is very different today from the one the last time Twitter had RSS support. And we can do *all* this with the existing Twitter API. Important point. No waiting. [link]

### I am tweeting via RSS

This is a thread that will turn into a longish element in my RSS feed of tweets.

Somewhere in the middle of this thread I will provide the URL of the feed.
I'm using GitHub to store the RSS feed, because GitHub has a bunch of very sophisticated notification services that I think might add to the RSS experience.
It might even make the RSS world-of-tweets perform at the scale of [link]? Certainly better than any server I could deploy. ;-)
RSS definitely could use another look given the reality of  server cost and performance of 2022. Last time we did this work was maybe 15 years ago?

### Another test

I have the feed working, I think.

This will test that. 

If it works, I will see this as a titled item in my RSS reader. The title will be "Another test".

Each of the paragraphs will be enclosed in an HTML paragraph element.

Here goes nothing! 🙏🏽
And this is what that tweet looks like in the feed. Check it out -- it has a title! That's new. [link]

### Markdown document titles

I'm pretty sure Markdown does not have the concept of the title of a document.

But titles are important. RSS has the concept of a title because many blog posts have titles.

### cont'd

Tweets don't have titles, but they could.

And that would make the match betw Twitter and RSS work, where the last time it was tried it didn't.

I believe this was the reason it didn't work.

### cont'd

Also I think I just figured out how to hook up threads to RSS feed items that are longer than 280 chars.

Why didn't I figure this out sooner?
